dn29:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans in a stilt longhouse in a mango grove belonging to those Sakyans named Vedhaññā.
dn29:1.3: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had recently passed away at Pāvā.
dn29:1.4: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
dn29:1.5: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
dn29:1.6: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.
dn29:1.7: And the Jain Ñātika’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.
dn29:2.1: And then, after completing the rainy season residence near Pāvā, the novice Cunda went to see Venerable Ānanda at Sāma village. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
dn29:2.5: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
dn29:2.6: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and tell him about this.”
dn29:3.1: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
dn29:4.1: “That’s what happens, Cunda, when a teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
dn29:4.2: Take the case where a teacher is not awakened, and the teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
dn29:4.3: A disciple in that teaching does not practice in line with the teaching, does not practice following that procedure, does not live in line with the teaching. They proceed having turned away from that teaching.
dn29:4.4: You should say this to them,
dn29:4.5: ‘You’re fortunate, reverend, you’re so very fortunate!
dn29:4.6: For your teacher is not awakened, and their teaching is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
dn29:4.7: But you don’t practice in line with that teaching, you don’t practice following that procedure, you don’t live in line with the teaching. You proceed having turned away from that teaching.’
dn29:4.8: In such a case the teacher and the teaching are to blame, but the disciple deserves praise.
dn29:4.9: Suppose someone was to say to such a disciple,
dn29:4.10: ‘Come on, venerable, practice as taught and pointed out by your teacher.’
dn29:4.11: The one who encourages, the one who they encourage, and the one who practices accordingly all brim with much wickedness.

dn29:10.0: 5. On the Incomplete Spiritual Path, Etc.
dn29:10.1: Now suppose, Cunda, that a spiritual path possesses those factors. But the teacher is not senior, long standing, long gone forth, advanced in years, and reached the final stage of life.
dn29:10.2: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.
dn29:10.3: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior,
dn29:10.4: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.
dn29:11.1: Now suppose that a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior. But there are no senior monk disciples who are competent, educated, assured, have attained sanctuary from the yoke,
dn29:11.2: who can rightly explain the true teaching, and who can legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up, and teach with a demonstrable basis.
dn29:11.3: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.
dn29:12.1: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks,
dn29:12.3: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.
dn29:12.4: Now suppose that a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks.
dn29:12.6: But there are no competent middle monks,
dn29:12.15: There are white-clothed laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures, but the spiritual path is not successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans …
dn29:12.16: the spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans, but it has not reached the peak of material things and fame.
dn29:12.17: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.
dn29:13.1: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks,
dn29:13.12: and the spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans, and it has reached the peak of material things and fame,
dn29:13.13: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.
dn29:14.1: I, Cunda, am a teacher who has arisen in the world today, perfected and fully awakened.
dn29:14.2: The teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is fully awakened.
dn29:14.3: My disciples have been educated in the meaning of that good teaching. And the spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure has been disclosed and revealed to them with all its collected sayings, with its demonstrable basis, well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.
dn29:14.4: I am a teacher today who is senior, long standing, long gone forth, advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life.
dn29:15.1: I have today disciples who are competent senior monks,
dn29:15.12: Today my spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.
dn29:16.1: Of all the teachers in the world today, Cunda, I don’t see even a single one who has reached the peak of material things and fame like me.
dn29:16.2: Of all the spiritual communities and groups in the world today, Cunda, I don’t see even a single one who has reached the pinnacle of material things and fame like the mendicant Saṅgha.
dn29:16.4: And if there’s any spiritual path of which it may be rightly said that
dn29:16.5: it’s endowed with all good qualities, complete in all good qualities, neither too little nor too much, well explained, whole, full, and well propounded,
dn29:16.6: it’s of this spiritual path that this should be said.
dn29:16.8: Uddaka son of Rāma used to say:
dn29:16.10: But seeing what does one not see?
dn29:16.11: You can see the blade of a well-sharpened razor, but not the edge.
dn29:16.14: But that saying of Uddaka’s is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless, as it’s only about a razor.
dn29:16.15: If there’s anything of which it may be rightly said:
dn29:16.16: ‘Seeing, one does not see,’ it’s of this that it should be said.
dn29:16.18: Seeing what does one not see?
dn29:16.19: One sees this: a spiritual path endowed with all good qualities, complete in all good qualities, neither too little nor too much, well explained, whole, full, and well propounded.
dn29:16.20: One does not see this: anything that, were it to be removed, would make it purer.
dn29:16.21: One does not see this: anything that, were it to be added, would make it more complete.
dn29:17.0: 6. Teachings Should be Recited in Concert
dn29:17.1: So, Cunda, you should all come together and recite in concert, without disputing, those things I have taught you from my direct knowledge, comparing meaning with meaning and phrasing with phrasing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
dn29:17.2: And what are those things I have taught from my direct knowledge?
dn29:17.3: They are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
dn29:17.4: These are the things I have taught from my own direct knowledge.

dn29:22.1: Cunda, I do not teach you solely for restraining defilements that affect this life.
dn29:22.2: Nor do I teach solely for protecting against defilements that affect lives to come.

dn29:23.6: These four kinds of indulgence in pleasure, Cunda, are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
dn29:23.8: It’s when some fool makes themselves happy and pleased by killing living creatures.
dn29:23.9: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.
dn29:23.10: Furthermore, someone makes themselves happy and pleased by theft.
dn29:23.11: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.

dn29:23.13: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.
dn29:23.14: Furthermore, someone amuses themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
dn29:23.15: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.
dn29:23.16: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure that are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

dn29:24.4: It isn’t right to say that about you; it misrepresents you with an untruth.
dn29:24.5: Cunda, these four kinds of indulgence in pleasure lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
dn29:24.7: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn29:24.8: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.
dn29:24.9: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption. It has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn29:24.10: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.
dn29:24.11: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
dn29:24.12: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.
dn29:24.13: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. It is without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
dn29:24.14: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.
dn29:24.15: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure which lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

dn29:25.0: 10. The Benefits of Indulgence in Pleasure
dn29:25.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
dn29:25.2: ‘How many fruits and benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways?’
dn29:25.4: ‘Four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.
dn29:25.6: Firstly, with the ending of three fetters a mendicant becomes a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.
dn29:25.7: This is the first fruit and benefit.
dn29:25.8: Furthermore, a mendicant—with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion—becomes a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.
dn29:25.9: This is the second fruit and benefit.
dn29:25.10: Furthermore, with the ending of the five lower fetters, a mendicant is reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
dn29:25.11: This is the third fruit and benefit.
dn29:25.12: Furthermore, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
dn29:25.13: This is the fourth fruit and benefit.
dn29:25.14: These four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’
dn29:26.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
dn29:26.2: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan are fickle.’
dn29:26.4: ‘Reverends, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.
dn29:26.5: Suppose there was an Indra’s pillar or an iron pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.
dn29:26.6: In the same way, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.
dn29:26.7: A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in nine respects.
dn29:26.8: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a layperson. And they can’t make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, or cowardice.
dn29:26.9: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these nine respects.’
dn29:27.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,
dn29:27.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama demonstrates boundless knowledge and vision of the past, but not of the future. What’s up with that?’
dn29:27.3: Those wanderers, like incompetent fools, seem to imagine that one kind of knowledge and vision can be demonstrated by means of another kind of knowledge and vision.
dn29:27.4: Regarding the past, the Realized One has knowledge stemming from memory.
dn29:27.5: He recollects as far as he wants.
dn29:27.6: Regarding the future, the Realized One has the knowledge born of awakening:
dn29:27.7: ‘This is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
dn29:28.1: If a question about the past is untrue, false, and pointless, the Realized One does not reply.
dn29:28.2: If a question about the past is true and correct, but pointless, he does not reply.
dn29:28.3: If a question about the past is true, correct, and beneficial, he knows the right time to reply.
dn29:28.4: And the Realized One replies to questions about the future or the present in the same way.
dn29:28.8: And so the Realized One has speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
dn29:29.1: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind, all that has been understood by the Realized One.
dn29:29.2: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
dn29:29.3: From the night when the Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with no residue—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.
dn29:29.4: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
dn29:29.5: The Realized One does as he says, and says as he does.
dn29:29.6: Since this is so, that’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.
dn29:29.7: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—the Realized One is the vanquisher, the unvanquished, the universal seer, the wielder of power.
dn29:30.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say,

dn29:30.19: ‘This too has not been declared by the Buddha.’

dn29:31.4: ‘Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That’s why it hasn’t been declared by the Buddha.’
